Posts.Content: You don't need our advice. If any woman found these she would have gone straight away to the doctor. What are you waiting for? Breast cancer is not just a disease for women. We all have them. Now GO. a Someone tell me again. What the H is a stone?
Posts.Signature: May The Odds Be Ever In Your Favour. Born 1960. Diagnosed 4/2011 with one tumor, LUL, NSCLC. Tumor size 1.1 inches. Thoracic surgery 6/1/2011. No action taken. Eight weeks of radiation and chemo. Carbo and Taxol. Follow up with four rounds of Carbo and Alimta. December 2011 CT scan shows all clear. April 2012 CT scan shows all clear. July 2012 had several x-rays taken at the chiropractor for shoulder pain. Took them to the onc and nothing suspicious noted. See them again in Oct. October didn't work out. Pain in the left shoulder continued to worsen and lymph nodes in the supraclavical swelled so I called the onc and they bumped the regular scan up to September 19 and we went for the results on the 24th. The tumor is back and the spread is extensive. Option 1: Try targeting chemos that may work and then on to clinical trials. These would give me about a year or so if the cancer responds. Option 2: Do no treatment and let nature take its course. This will give me six months give or take. As good as I feel right now, Im going for door #2 and will continue to live well and enjoy myself until I dont. Ill keep you posted. Live it up everyone! 7 months into hospice and palliative care. It has been a very good relationship with the organization as a whole with a minor glitch. April 2013 spent the night at hospice facility, PICC line inserted for morphine drip. I said I wouldnt but, had a hospital bed delivered. Started 10 rounds of palliative radiation to shrink the neck tumor. Busy month for me! I've taken a couple of nasty falls this last week. (first of & mid-May) Right on the cancer shoulder. So I have a life alert necklace on me now. I wish I could get my hands on a small scooter! There is another node swelling on the other side of my neck. Still small. April51's (Jody) daughter posted that her Mother's journey in this world had ended on July 8th 2013.You touched so very many lives. Soar high Jody!
Posts.Title: Could I have breast cancer

Posts.Content: Definatley take a deep breath. Pick your battles. It sounds like you were on shakey ground to begin with. The person who doesn't have the cancer has a very hard time grasping how hard it is and what goes through your head every minute of every day. a

Posts.Title: Support for your spouse

Posts.Content: Hi all, my cousin got her bad news today. We are both originally from Palm Beach Florida and, of course she is in a panic, and is thinking of going back there for tx. I have a problem with that as their funds are limited and I found excelent care for lung cancer right here at home in Cincy. She lives in the high desert in LA county. Does anyone know of a good tx center there? Thanks so much, a

Posts.Title: BC treatment in Lancaster, CA

Posts.Content: Well, here we go. Don't you think I have been on every google there is known to man?

Posts.Title: Clinical trials

Posts.Signature: May The Odds Be Ever In Your Favour. Born 1960. Diagnosed 4/2011 with one tumor, LUL, NSCLC. Tumor size 1.1 inches. Thoracic surgery 6/1/2011. No action taken. Eight weeks of radiation and chemo. Carbo and Taxol. Follow up with four rounds of Carbo and Alimta. December 2011 CT scan shows all clear. April 2012 CT scan shows all clear. July 2012 had several x-rays taken at the chiropractor for shoulder pain. Took them to the onc and nothing suspicious noted. See them again in Oct. October didn't work out. Pain in the left shoulder continued to worsen and lymph nodes in the supraclavical swelled so I called the onc and they bumped the regular scan up to September 19 and we went for the results on the 24th. The tumor is back and the spread is extensive. Option 1: Try targeting chemos that may work and then on to clinical trials. These would give me about a year or so if the cancer responds. Option 2: Do no treatment and let nature take its course. This will give me six months give or take. As good as I feel right now, Im going for door #2 and will continue to live well and enjoy myself until I dont. Ill keep you posted. Live it up everyone! 7 months into hospice and palliative care. It has been a very good relationship with the organization as a whole with a minor glitch. April 2013 spent the night at hospice facility, PICC line inserted for morphine drip. I said I wouldnt but, had a hospital bed delivered. Started 10 rounds of palliative radiation to shrink the neck tumor. Busy month for me! I've taken a couple of nasty falls this last week. (first of & mid-May) Right on the cancer shoulder. So I have a life alert necklace on me now. I wish I could get my hands on a small scooter! There is another node swelling on the other side of my neck. Still small. April51's (Jody) daughter posted that her Mother's journey in this world had ended on July 8th 2013.You touched so very many lives. Soar high Jody!
Posts.Title: Clinical trials

Posts.Content: I'm so glad you chose treatment. At least you can give it a try and if you don't like it, you can always quit. what you can't do is go back and do curative chemo in advanced stages. jody

Posts.Title: Anyone just not want to do it?

Posts.Content: Gott, It sounds too suspicious to me. Keep doing your homework and don't let up on the docs. It is always hard for family members when you have someone like me hounding them to get checked and checked again. Good luck and good health. a I don't know how other people find out they have cancer, but a lot of people with lung cancer find out on what seems to be a fluke. I went for about two months being not quite sick and not quite well. Shortness of breath, tired. I INSISTED on a chest x-ray. It was mentioned that I should have had one earlier. Insurance didn't pay and the doctor didn't go that route. Insurance changed and so did the doc. Sooooo. I have a love/hate relationship with health insurance. a
Posts.Signature: May The Odds Be Ever In Your Favour. Born 1960. Diagnosed 4/2011 with one tumor, LUL, NSCLC. Tumor size 1.1 inches. Thoracic surgery 6/1/2011. No action taken. Eight weeks of radiation and chemo. Carbo and Taxol. Follow up with four rounds of Carbo and Alimta. December 2011 CT scan shows all clear. April 2012 CT scan shows all clear. July 2012 had several x-rays taken at the chiropractor for shoulder pain. Took them to the onc and nothing suspicious noted. See them again in Oct. October didn't work out. Pain in the left shoulder continued to worsen and lymph nodes in the supraclavical swelled so I called the onc and they bumped the regular scan up to September 19 and we went for the results on the 24th. The tumor is back and the spread is extensive. Option 1: Try targeting chemos that may work and then on to clinical trials. These would give me about a year or so if the cancer responds. Option 2: Do no treatment and let nature take its course. This will give me six months give or take. As good as I feel right now, Im going for door #2 and will continue to live well and enjoy myself until I dont. Ill keep you posted. Live it up everyone! 7 months into hospice and palliative care. It has been a very good relationship with the organization as a whole with a minor glitch. April 2013 spent the night at hospice facility, PICC line inserted for morphine drip. I said I wouldnt but, had a hospital bed delivered. Started 10 rounds of palliative radiation to shrink the neck tumor. Busy month for me! I've taken a couple of nasty falls this last week. (first of & mid-May) Right on the cancer shoulder. So I have a life alert necklace on me now. I wish I could get my hands on a small scooter! There is another node swelling on the other side of my neck. Still small. Posts.Title: How did you find out you had cancer?
